Heller to speak here on March 6
By PATRICE GALLAGHER
Joseph Heller, author of
Catch-22 and the recently published Something Happened, will
speak at this year's Milford H.
Whitehill Lecture Series.
The program, sponsored by
Omicron Delta Kappa, an honor
society for student leaders, will
take place March 6 at 8 pm in
Shriver Hall. In past years, the
series has brought such figures as
Senator Thomas Eagleton and
Alger Hiss to Hopkins.
ODK President Jeff Greve
guided the selection of Heller as
the Lectureship's 1975 speaker.
"The premise of the series is to
have speakers who are leaders in
their field,- he explained.
"I thought that since he's con-

temporary and certainly a leader
in his field, he'd be interesting to
listen to," said Greve. "I talked
to his agent and he apparently is
anxious to speak here."
Heller, born in Brooklyn,
N.Y., was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of New York University. He
holds a master's degree in American Lieterature from Columbia
University and studied at Oxford
University for one year on a Fulbright Scholarship.
After college, he taught freshman English and expository writing for two years at Pennsylvania
State College.
Heller began his first novel
Catch-22, in 1953, writing it evenings after work and on occassional weekend afternoons. He

completed it in:1961. Prior to the
novel's publication, he worked
for several years as an advertising
promotion writer with a number
of large New York firms. More
than eight million copies of
Catch-22 have been sold worldwide.
He also wrote a play in 1966,
entitled We Bombed in New
Haven which ran on Broadway
for twelve weeks in 1968. His
second novel, Something Happened, was published in October,
1974.
Heller has been a faculty member of the City College of New
York's English Department for
the past four years, conducting
graduate and undergraduate
courses in the writing of fiction.

charged with evaluating the viability of the present University
Honor system will do a great injustice to the Honor
Commission if it proceeds on the grave suppositions
expressed by SC President Andy Savitz. Savitz and other
critics of the present system—including, astonishingly
enough, Honor Commission Chairwoman Ann Connor—have
pointed to a lack of cooperation on the part of students and
faculty in reporting cheating, and technical errors in trial
procedure as justification for a re-evaluation and perhaps
alteration of the Honor system. We feel, however, that these
temporary and correctable difficulties should not lead the
committee to contemplate major changes in the system.
By scrutinizing the particulars of the Commission's
function—and emerging triumphantly with documented
criticism—Savitz and Connor have failed, we feel, to consider
that an Honor Commission is not intended to be a busy and
well-oiled grand jury. Its impact is mainly theatrical—it
attempts to discourage cheating not by actually ferreting out
any substantial amount of miscreants, but by demonstrating
for all the student body to see the terrible punishment
reserved for offenders.
Thus, criticism that not enough convictions have been
arrived at or that students shirk their responsibility to uphold
the Honor code does not show any deficiency on the part of
the Honor system. It does show that faculty and students
have not lived up to the spirit of the Honor code, not that
the Commission or the system has failed. Though we agree
with Savitz and Connor that students and faculty must better
uphold the system, we do not feel that their failure to do so
to date justifies compromising the Honor system. Students
and faculty must be made to bear the burden of
responsibility in upholding the Honor code. They can't very
well refuse, can they?

uphold the system, we do not feel that their failure to do so
